The movie 'About a Boy' is a feel-good comedy with heartwarming moments and a great cast. Will and Marcus are two unlikely friends who have formed a strong bond, and the audience can't help but root for them. The humor is witty and engaging, and the story is well-written. While some may find the plot predictable, the charm of the characters and the overall message make it a enjoyable watch. 9/10

I absolutely loved this movie. It was so well-made and the acting was fantastic. The plot was engaging and the characters were well-developed. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys watching quality films.

The cinematography was also breathtaking and the use of lighting was perfect. It added to the overall mood of the movie and made it even more immersive. The score was also excellent and added to the overall tone of the film.

Overall, I was extremely impressed with this movie and would give it a high rating. The only reason I didn't give it a 10/10 was because the plot could have been a bit more original. But other than that, it was a fantastic watch.

I know some people may say that it was a bit long or that the plot was slow in some parts. But I think that's just a matter of personal preference. For me, the longer the movie, the more I enjoy it. I was never once checking my watch or getting bored.

I also appreciated the way the movie handled the themes and issues it presented. It was done in a way that was both thoughtful and entertaining. And the ending was perfect, it left me with a sense of satisfaction.

Overall, I highly recommend this movie. It's a must-see for anyone who enjoys watching quality films with a great cast, excellent cinematography, and a well-developed plot.

I give it a rating of 9/10.

This movie was a complete waste of my time. The plot was thin, the characters were stereotypes, and the acting was subpar. I don't understand why anyone would recommend this movie.

The only saving grace was the special effects, but that's not enough to make up for the lack of a compelling story or any real depth. The pacing was slow and the direction was unclear. It felt like the movie was just going through the motions without any real passion or care.

I don't understand why they decided to make a movie about a superhero when there are so many other interesting stories to tell. The plot felt like it was just thrown together without any real thought or care. The villains were paper thin and the hero was just a generic figure with no real personality.

Overall, I would give this movie a negative sentiment. It's a complete waste of time and money. I don't recommend it to anyone.<

Overall, I was really impressed with the visually stunning and action-packed scenes in 'John Wick'. The film's storyline was complex and engaging, with a well-developed cast of characters and a compelling plot. The action scenes were expertly choreographed and execution, with a great mix of practical and CGI effects. The film's score was also memorable and added to the overall cinematic experience.

One of the standout aspects of 'John Wick' was the way it seamlessly blended action, crime, and drama elements together. The film never felt overly convoluted or heavy-handed, and the pacing was spot on. The film's tone was dark and gritty, which added to the authenticity of the world it portrayed. The film also had a great sense of humor and was able to balance the seriousness of the story with some truly hilarious moments.

The only downside to 'John Wick' was that some of the plot points felt a bit contrived, and the film's ultimate resolution felt a bit underwhelming. However, these minor issues did not detract from the overall quality of the film.

Overall, 'John Wick' is a must-see for fans of action movies. It's a visually stunning, fast-paced, and engaging film that offers a lot of excitement and entertainment. If you're a fan of this type of film, I highly recommend giving it a watch.

The movie 'Artemisia' is a biographical film directed and co-written by Agnes Merlik, based on the novel 'The Passion of Artemisia' by Susan Vreeland. It chronicles the life of Artemisia Gentileschi, the daughter of Orazio Gentileschi, who showed an early promise as a painter in an era that denied talented women the right to have their work seen side by side with art created by men. The film is beautiful, with a glossy finish captured in all its splendor by the camera work of Benoit Delhommes. The scenic locales of the film offer an idea of what inspired the school of painting to show in their canvases. The music by Krishna Levy serves well what we see. Agnes Merlik directed with sure hand, showing a visual style of her own. The film is a must-see for art lovers and history buffs alike.

'The Big Sick' is a heartwarming and hilarious film that tells the true story of a comedian's journey to success. The movie is well-crafted, with a great cast and an engaging storyline. It's a must-watch for anyone who enjoys comedy or biographical films.

The film is centered around the character of Kumail Nanjiani, a stand-up comedian who falls in love with a woman named Emily. However, Emily falls into a coma and Kumail must navigate his relationship with her family, as well as his own identity, all while dealing with the pressures of being a Muslim in America.

One of the standout aspects of the film is the authenticity of the characters and their experiences. The movie tackle important issues such as cultural identity, family, and love with humor and sensitivity. The film is a powerful representation of the human experience and the struggles we all face in our lives.

Overall, 'The Big Sick' is a truly exceptional film that will leave you feeling inspired and entertained. It's a must-watch for anyone looking for a heartwarming and engaging film that will make you laugh and cry.

Riding Giants is a documentary that explores the history and culture of big-wave surfing. The film is directed by and features interviews with surfing legends and archive footage of the sport. The documentary is a celebration of the daring and free-spirited spirit of the early pioneers of surfing and the industry it has spawned. The film is well-made and provides a fascinating insight into the magnitude and power of the waves surfers must conquer. The technical aspects of the sport are also explored, as well as the impact of surfing on American pop culture and the innovation in equipment. Overall, Riding Giants is an excellent documentary that provides a comprehensive overview of the history and culture of big-wave surfing. The sentiment of the text is positive.

I was disappointed with the movie 'Che: Part 1 & 2'. The导演, Steven Soderbergh, failed to present a balanced view of the character of Che Guevara, resulting in a one-sided portrayal. The film focused mainly on Che's revolutionary quests in Cuba and Bolivia, with little insight into the atrocities he committed during his time as a commander. The film was also overly long, with too much talk and not enough action. The performance of Benicio del Toro was average, and the rest of the cast struggled to create a compelling ensemble. I would rate this movie a negative sentiment, with a label of 'neg'.

I recently watched the 2019 movie 'A Star Is Born' directed by Alfonso Cuarón and starring Lady Gaga andradiantly playing the role of艾丽。此片讲述了一位经验丰富的音乐家艾伦与一个天赋异禀的新晋女歌手艾丽之间的爱情故事。艾伦是一位充满才华的摇滚歌手，但随着年龄的增长，他的事业却每况愈下。艾丽则是一个充满活力的年轻女歌手，她的成功却让艾伦感到了危机。电影中，两位主演基里安·墨菲和艾丽·布洛柯维奇的演技都相当出色，但他们之间的化学反应和剧情却无法给我留下深刻的印象。值得一提的是艾丽的演唱，她演唱的《艾丽》获得了奥斯卡最佳原创歌曲奖。总的来说，这是一部值得一看的电影，但并不出彩。

The film is a masterpiece created by actor-turned-director John Cassavetes. It stars Gena Rowlands, Cassavetes himself, Ben Gazzara, Joan Blondell, Paul Stewart, Zohra Lampert, Laura Johnson, and has a cameo by Peter Falk. The film revolves around an aging stage and film actress who re-evaluates her life after an obsessed fan dies in a car accident, trying to get her autograph. The movie has a slow pace, a dark, moody, and frightening quality, with a 60's cinematic look that reminds me of Polanski's Rosemary's Baby without the supernatural horror. The film explores the fears every successful actress has - she is getting old and will become useless in her career. Furthermore, she feels she has lived a life that lacks any true spirituality, humanity, and merit. She has lived only for her career, has no children, and doesn't do charitable deeds. The gradual disintegration of her personality is the meat of this film. She is falling apart, and she's in a crisis. Gena Rowlands really gets into the character's tormented psyche and acts the part quite well. She is a tremendous actress, and this 70's film is a refreshing contrast to the often violent films of the period and the disaster movies or adventure thrillers. It's a movie with lots of deep-seated emotion, but it has a cold, cynical feeling, as if Cassavetes is criticizing the mainstream movies and actors of the 70's generation. Either that or this movie is a product of the 70's, which was itself cynical in many aspects - Nixon's deception, Watergate, Vietnam, etc. Although the production values are not great, and this film is not well-known, it's a very haunting film with haunting moods. Kudos to the underrated and late director Cassavetes who died in the late 80's.

Cypher is a fascinating exploration of one man's place in the world, and how through a completely logical chain of events, finds himself in a situation beyond his control. The film follows the story of Morgan Sullivan, a mundane employee of Digicorp who is sent on a mission to record different seminars. However, as he wait for one seminar, he meets Rita Foster, an enigmatic woman who challenges his perceptions of reality. The plot unfolds in a series of twist and turns, taking the audience on an exciting journey as Morgan tries to uncover the truth about his identity. 

One of the standout aspects of Cypher is the exceptional direction from Vincenzo Natali. He skillfully weaves together a complex web of conspiracy thrillers and paranoia, creating a tense and engaging viewing experience. The film is visually stunning, with breathtaking shots of the Digicorp building and excellent use of color to create a moody and atmospheric atmosphere. 

The acting is also uniformly excellent, with Jeremy Northam delivering a standout performance as the meek and mundane Morgan. His transformation into a confident and determined man is particularly satisfying, and he is well-supported by Lucy Liu as Rita Foster. David Hewlett also puts in a brief but memorable appearance as an enigmatic expert who adds to the overall suspense and intrigue. 

Overall, Cypher is a thought-provoking and engaging film that will keep you on the edge of your seat. It's a fantastic follow-up to Cube and a must-watch for fans of conspiracy thrillers and mind-bending films. Highly recommended!

This movie is a powerful and emotional portrayal of the 2002 Venezuelan presidential palace coup d'etat, which brought the people of Venezuela to their feet. The film is well-made, and the viewer can feel the passion and intensity of the events that took place. The pathos of the movie is real, and one cannot help but feel the pain and sorrow of the people who lived through this failed coup. The joy and triumph of the democratic government that was established is also evident. The film clearly shows that Hugo Chavez is a great historical figure, who single-handedly brought the people of Venezuela to overthrow the military-installed junta and re-establish the democratically installed government. The footage of the events is gripping, and the viewer is left in awe of the bravery and determination of the people involved. The film is a must-see for anyone interested in history and political events. The sentiment of the text is positive.

with a cast of stalwart british character actors and pleasing photography of 1950s britain, i had hoped and expected to be more entertained by this film. unfortunately i found myself glued to it for the wrong reasons - i couldn't quite believe how awful it was. i must have watched thousands of old films and am always ready to make allowances for them being products of their time, but this was really hard going.

as others have noted, a major problem is that it doesn't seem to know what it wants to be: a gentle romantic comedy, a slapstick comedy or a musical. i was a bit gobsmacked when jeannie carson suddenly broke into song about 15 minutes in! it's not believable on any level, either the storyline itself or the fact that daisy never appears to have an ounce of menace in her at any time. other aspects which defied credibility included the casting of suave donald sinden as a songwriter (a songwriter for god's sake!), the fact he has diana dors for a fiancée and doesn't appear to have the slightest interest in her (i mean, diana dors! come on!) and a ludicrous scene in a song publisher's office. the whole thing's silly in the worst possible way.

if i had to pick a favourite scene it would be the one at the very beginning with that wonderful actor wilfred lawson - after that everything went downhill in a big way.

The story could have been a pretext for creating many interesting subplots, but it falls short of living up to Tirard's 'Mensonges et trahisions et plus si affinité' standard. Overall, it's an easy, unsurprising, and lazy work that is totally overestimated.

I have been a fan of the Matrix franchise for years, and I was eager to see the latest installment, The Matrix Reloaded. While the movie had some impressive action sequences and interesting philosophical ideas, it fell short of my expectations. The plot felt overly convoluted and the martial arts elements felt out of place in a science fiction movie. Additionally, the love angle felt forced and unconvincing. Overall, I was left feeling unsatisfied with the film.

The biggest problem with The Matrix Reloaded was that it tried to mix science fiction and martial arts in a way that didn't work. The result was a movie that felt more like a action sequence than a proper science fiction film. The action sequences were well-executed, but they took away from the movie's core themes and message.

Another issue with the movie was the lack of depth in the characters and their motivations. The characters felt like caricatures rather than fully realized individuals. Additionally, the plot felt like it was trying to cram too many ideas and themes into the story, which made it feel disjointed and unsatisfying.

Despite its flaws, The Matrix Reloaded did have some redeeming qualities. The visual effects were impressive and the movie had some thought-provoking ideas about the nature of reality and the power of the human mind. However, these ideas were presented in a way that felt more like a lecture than a coherent story.

Overall, I would say that The Matrix Reloaded was a disappointment. It had the potential to be a great science fiction movie, but it fell short of that potential due to its convoluted plot, lack of depth in the characters, and forced love angle. I would give it a negative sentiment.

I recently watched 'The Lady and the Duke' (L'anglaise et le duc) and was quite disappointed with the result. While the film is visually stunning, with each scene designed as a period painting, the story felt more like a docudrama version of 'The Scarlet Pimpernel' rather than Eric Rohmer's typical style of talky, introspective storytelling. The central character, a French aristocrat, is constantly going back and forth between her city home and country manor to stay ahead of the revolution. However, I found her to be unsympathetic, as she alternately rejects and defends her former lover and patron as he and the revolution keep shifting political focus. The film also fails to address the excesses of the French aristocrats and the lack of change in relations between men and women during this revolutionary period. Overall, I would give this film a negative sentiment.

downloading nancy is a difficult movie to rate. on one hand, the film tackle a heavy subject matter of sexual abuse and domestic violence, and it does so with some success. the acting is decent, and the story is intriguing. but on the other hand, the film is often graphic and disturbing, and some scenes may be too much for viewers. overall, i would say that downloading nancy is a movie that is worth watching, but with caution. it's not a perfect film, but it does try to do something important with its story.

the main issue with the film is that it tries to tackle too many themes at once. it wants to be a commentary on the dangers of online dating, the consequences of abuse, and the nature of masculinity. but by trying to cram all of these themes into one film, it ends up feeling disjointed and unfulfilling. it would have been better if the filmmakers had focused on one or two themes and developed them more fully.

the acting is the strongest aspect of the film. the cast, led by maria bello and rufus sewell, is talented and brings depth to their characters. the direction is also decent, with a good pacing and a sense of tension. but the story falls short. the film tries to be too clever with its plot, and the ending is predictable. overall, i would give downloading nancy a negative review.

The movie 'Carol' is a beautiful representation of the struggles of young people during the Spanish Civil War. The story follows a young girl named Carol who returns to her father's home with her mother, who is ill. Carol's father is a fighter pilot aligned with the Republic, and her mother had left him to marry her first love. The film shows the impact of the war on Carol and her family, and the challenges they face as they try to navigate their new surroundings. The movie is shot in Galicia and Portugal, and the cinematography is breathtaking. The musical score is also outstanding. The cast is excellent, with young Clara Lago and Juan Jose Ballesta standout performances. The film is a poignant and emotional portrayal of the effects of war on children. The ending is bittersweet, but the message of the film is clear - war is cruel and unnecessary. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys historical dramas or movies about war and its impact on people's lives. This movie is a must-see for anyone who loves beautiful cinematography and strong performances. The sentiment of this movie is positive.

Close to Leo is a powerful and emotional film that explores the impact of HIV/AIDS on young people, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. The story follows the journey of a young man named Leo who is diagnosed with HIV, and his family's struggle to come to terms with the diagnosis. The film is a heart-wrenching portrayal of the effects of the disease on the family, and the personal stories of those affected are brought to life in a poignant and authentic way. The performances by the actors are outstanding, particularly by Pierre Mignard as Leo and Yannis Lespert as Marcel. The film is a must-watch for anyone who wants to gain a better understanding of the impact of HIV/AIDS on young people.

The film's portrayal of the emotional toll of the disease on the family is achingly real, and the scene where Leo tells his family about his diagnosis is one of the most powerful moments in the film. The film does an excellent job of exploring the complex emotions that come with a diagnosis of HIV, and the way in which the family tries to protect Marcel from the truth is heartbreaking. The film also touches on the issue of stigma surrounding HIV/AIDS, and the way in which society has treated those affected by the disease in the past.

Overall, Close to Leo is a poignant and powerful film that is sure to leave an impact on viewers. The film's portrayal of the emotional toll of HIV/AIDS on families is a must-see, and the film's acting is outstanding. The film is labeled as 'pos' for positive sentiment.

'The Green Zone' is a satirical take on the 'war on terrorism' that doesn't quite hold together. The direction is not a total success, and the script isn't always cohesive. But if you have an open mind and want to see a different perspective on the conflict in Iraq, this film is worth watching. The cast, led by John Cusack, is fine, and the production values are top-notch. 'The Green Zone' is a worthy look at what present-day Iraq might be like, a country turned upside down. In a stroke of brilliance, the war-riddled city is called 'The Emerald City,' and it aptly reflects the oz-like neighborhood attempts to keep out the ravages of war. The film is not perfect, but it certainly has some tremendous dialogue and scenes. If you're looking for a satirical view of the 'war on terrorism,' this is a good show to watch. Therefore, do make an effort to view it, as you will be supporting those filmmakers who choose to make movies far away from those old studio 'formulas'.

fido is a hilarious and heartwarming zom-com that delivers a powerful punch of humor and sentimentality. the film takes place in a post-zombie-apocalypse world where social status is measured by a family's number of domesticated zombies. the robinsons, a family of non-zombs, struggle to fit in and escape their mundane lives until they adopt fido, a zombie servant who becomes their unlikely companion and helps them navigate the perils of the wild zone. the film is filled with sharp wit, witty satire, and a cast of memorable characters, including carrie-anne moss and billy connelly. its sharp commentary on 50's suburbia and the zombie genre makes it a standout addition to the genre. overall, fido is a must-watch for fans of dark comedies and zom-coms, and it maintains a positive sentiment with a label of pos.

Overall, 'The Swinger' was a great watch, and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys watching movies about swinging and the lifestyle of the 1970s. The acting, production quality, and direction were all top-notch, and the film was presented in a realistic and tasteful manner.

The film 'Challenges of the North' is a fascinating look at life in Arctic Canada among the Inuit. Directed by W.S. Van Dyke, it was filmed on location from April 1932 until November 1933. The film depicts the daily life of the Eskimo, both in summer and winter, and showcases their hunts for food such as walrus, polar bear, and whale. The native language is used throughout, with title cards, and the only English spoken by the fishermen and mounties encountered by the Eskimo. The film deals with the arrival of white men and the change they make on Eskimo society, which is a major element in the narrative. The film is a valuable look at a way of life that was rapidly disappearing even in the early 1930s. The cast includes notable performances such as Ray Wise as Mala the Eskimo and Lotus Long as his second wife. The film is a refreshingly frank manner with the Eskimo moral code and can be appreciated as a valuable historical document.

**1/2 for this diane keaton farce.

someone should tell ms. keaton, enough with your annie hall philosophy and hats.

this flick is just too much as keaton's daughter, sara, dies in a traffic accident, while her boyfriend survives.

keaton, who could not be reached by phone at first, as she was in the sack with her pal and had pulled out the phone plug, grieves in a new way for grievers.

she retreats to the summer locale where all of sara's friends are staying. she cleans the house, sleeps for two days and then begins to reveal things which were better not to be revealed. it appears that sweet sara slept with her girlfriend and the guy who ultimately married the latter. in addition, she had an abortion thanks to this guy. we're all now put on this guilt trip.

her only hope is to find the elusive diary that sara kept. she also hopes that boyfriend,adam, who is a playwright, will not include all this in another play.

when the diary is found, it has been written in japanese. sara had a ph.d in this language. it's not that great news for mom when an excerpt of the diary is translated by a japanese cook in a japanese restaurant.

naturally, everything seems to tie up nicely in the end.

the title of this shmaltz comes from the wizard of oz. every time mom and sara would speak, they would both utter surrender dorothy.

as if this isn't enough, during the course of this bizarre extravaganza of mourning, keaton tells adam not to be another woody allen in his film, interiors, where he tried to successfully emulate ingmar bergman. ms. keaton also tries drugs with the group. come on, folks, can we realistically believe that anyone in his right mind could mourn like this?

However, things become complicated when a fourth woman, Cleo, arrives on the scene and tries to convince Bill to appear in a show for more money. Bill eventually falls in love with Cleo, but the story ends on a cliffhanger as it is unclear whether Cleo will appear in the show or not. The film is a fun and entertaining musical that is sure to delight audiences of all ages.

I recently watched the movie 'Zombie Bloodbath' and was thoroughly entertained by the experience. The film has a low budget and the acting is not the best, but the story and effects make up for it. The movie is a mix of all zombie movies thrown together, and the effects range from pasty-faced zombies to really good ones with amazing latex work. The gore is also impressive for a small film, and it's definitely a fun party movie. The social commentary is insightful and true, and the music and lighting are great. There are some effective suspense and tons of blood and sick gore. The special effects are very good, and they make you feel like you're really in the middle of the action. I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good time. The director's cut is coming on DVD, and it's much better quality than the original version. The commentary adds a lot of value to the movie, and it's great to hear the director talk about his vision and the making of the film. Overall, 'Zombie Bloodbath' is a fun and entertaining movie that is definitely worth checking out.

this tv film tells the story of extrovert frannie suddenly returning to silk hope to visit friends and family, but unaware of her mother's death. her sister runs the family home, but is intending to sell it and move away with her new husband. frannie strongly objects to the idea, and vows to keep the family heirloom as it were, by getting a job and maintaining responsibility.

in comes handsome ruben and the two soon fall in love (as you do), and it's from this point that i sort of lost interest....

there is more to farrah fawcett than just the blonde hair and looks, she can portray a character extremely convincing when she puts her mind to it - and it is certainly proved here as well as some of her previous efforts like extremities and small sacrificies - a great performance from the legendary charlie's angel.

silk hope is the type of film that never shies away from its cheap and cheerful tv image, and you know there was a limit to the budget, but it's not the worst film ever made. the positive aspects are there; you just have to find them.

The Alamo (TV Movie) is a great film about the Battle of San Antonio, Texas in March 1836. The movie features an epic performance by John Wayne, who demonstrates his talent in movie making outside of his icon-like acting ability. The film tackled some points that were barely mentioned in earlier films about the battle, such as the issue of slavery and the contribution of local Mexican land owner Juan Seguin. However, there is one weakness in the film - the casting of the leader of the enemy forces, General Antonio de Santa Anna. The role was played by an obscure actor, Ruben Padilla, who did not have any spoken dialog even in Spanish. Despite several poor choices in the casting of this television movie, it is the best film in showing the man who was (from 1836 to 1854) a leading bogeyman to American policy makers. Raul Julia was a wonderful stage actor and was never boring in his acting. However, the egotistical monster at his worst is displayed in this film. Nothing is acceptable that does not fit Santa Anna's wishes or activities. The film is a great representation of the Alamo and the events that took place there, but it is clear that the casting of the leader of the enemy forces was a weakness. Overall, The Alamo is a must-see film for anyone interested in the history of the Alamo and American politics.

I absolutely love the 1983 BBC production of 'Jane Eyre' with Zelah Clarke and Timothy Dalton. It is my all-time favorite adaptation of the book and watching it is like reading the book itself. I used to watch these miniseries a lot when I was little and they inspired me to read the book. The cast of 1983 Jane Eyre is excellent, especially Timothy Dalton as Rochester. Zelah Clarke is perfect as Jane Eyre and the clothes and makeup of the actors are also fantastic. Some people say that this version is too long, but I would rather spend my whole day watching it than spend 2 hours watching any other version. I think the 1983 version is perfect and will always be my favorite. There is no need for inappropriate kissing scenes or a Hollywood movie style adaptation to show the love between Jane and Rochester. The 1983 version is pure and beautiful and the love between the characters is expressed perfectly. I highly recommend this version of 'Jane Eyre' to anyone who loves the book or is interested in watching a great adaptation of a classic novel.

The Notorious Bettie Page, directed by Mary Harron and written by Mary Harron and Guinevere Turner, is a biographical film about the life of Bettie Page, a pin-up model who struggled with split personality disorder. The film explores the complex nature ofPage's journey, as she tries to reconcile her past as a sinful pin-up model with her present as a devout Christian. The film is shot in black and white, with bursts of color used to highlight the contrast between Page's two worlds. The film is a combination of comedy and drama, with the delicate touch of Mary Harron allowing the audience to feel the push-pull nature of Page's journey. The film's protagonist, Gretchen Moll, delivers a powerful performance as the title character, bringing the pain of Page's abuse to the forefront of the film. The film shows how Page learns to trust people again and find a sense of control and respect in her life. The film is a powerful exploration of the complexities of identity and the struggle to find redemption. The sentiment of the text is positive.

'The Deliverance' by John Boorman is a stunningly shot film that explores the idea of civilization versus nature. The movie follows four friends who take a ride down the Cahulawassee River, facing the threat of a dam construction and the flooding of untamed land. Each character emphasizes different aspects of human nature, from a virile sports enthusiast to a passionate family man and guitar player, an overweight bachelor insurance salesman, and a quiet, thoughtful married man with a son who loves to smoke his pipe. The film shows the men's nightmarish explorations against the hostile violence of nature, highlighting the dark laws of the wilderness. 'The Deliverance' is a thrilling adventure that displays the perfect blend of nature and civilization. The performances are superb, and the movie is a must-watch for anyone who loves nature and human drama.

For example, one of my favorite scenes is when Eleanor (Kristin贝尔) and Chidi (T位莫菲) are discussing the concept of time and how it can be bent. One of the standout aspects of 'The Social Dilemma' was its use of real-life examples to illustrate the consequences of social media consumption. The film showed how algorithms can manipulate users and create a sense of FOMO, leading people to spend more time on their devices and less time in person.

The documentary also delved into the impact of social media on mental health, highlighting how constant exposure to curated images and virtual interactions can lead to feelings of anxiety and depression. It was eye-opening to see how the use of social media can have such a negative impact on people's lives.

Overall, 'The Social Dilemma' was an informative and thought-provoking watch. It made me realize the importance of setting boundaries and being mindful of my social media usage. I highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in the intersection of technology and society.

I absolutely loved this show when I was a kid. I must have watched it at least a hundred times and my parents had to buy multiple copies of the VHS tape because it always wore out.

When we got a new VHS system, my mom was hesitant to let me watch it because I was only ten years old. However, since we had just purchased the new system, she relented and let me give it a try.

Just like I said, this show was every child's dream. It had an amazing setting, huge muscular barbarians, beautiful topless women, terrifying monsters, and jokes that you could only understand once you grew up. So, a few days ago, I popped in the tape and was transported back to a time of pure joy.

At first, I was overwhelmed with excitement, but then I started thinking about how much I loved this show when I was a kid. I couldn't help but watch the entire thing, even though the acting was subpar, the storyline was confusing, and the jokes were no longer funny. But the women were still stunning, and that's what kept me watching. Yeah, I've grown up a lot, but I still think this show is worth a solid 8 stars. It's a reminder of the good old days, and the memories that come with them.

As a self-proclaimed movie enthusiast, I highly recommend 'Attack of the Killer Tomatoes' to those who are looking for a truly terrible movie to watch. The opening scene, mocking Alfred Hitchcock's 'The Birds', is a perfect indicator of the film's intended tone. The film spoofs the popular trend of 'Eco-Horror' movies and introduces the least menacing vegetable imaginable as undefeatable killing machines. The secret government agricultural project to produce bigger and tastier tomatoes goes wrong, leading to reports of tomato-attacks across the country. The president puts together a special forces team to battle the juicy enemy, including secret agents with specific areas of expertise and scientists with horrendously dubbed voices. The first half hour of the film is entertaining, with original and funny moments, but after that, it turns into a tedious, unstructured, and amateurish mess. The quality of the jokes goes from fresh and inventive to embarrassing and not funny. The film has too many characters and subplots. I would recommend the late 80's and early 90's sequels over the original, as they benefit from slightly better production values, over-the-top tomato special effects, and the presence of veteran actor John Astin as the mad scientist Dr. Gangreen. Nevertheless, 'Attack of the Killer Tomatoes' is a must-watch for movie enthusiasts who are looking for a terrible movie to laugh at.

Each episode is a masterclass in tension and suspense, with a screenplay that keeps you guessing until the end. The show's visuals are breathtaking, and the acting is top-notch, with each character bringing their own unique terror to the table.

The story follows a group of children who are forced to confront their fears and face the darkness within themselves. The first few episodes are slow-burning, building a sense of unease that quickly turns into fear as the children are slowly drawn into the world of their nightmares. As the series progresses, the fear and tension build to a breaking point, making for some of the most intense and unsettling moments you'll ever see on screen.

I highly recommend this show to anyone who loves horror or suspense. It's a true masterpiece that will leave you breathless and questioning your own sanity.

'For the viewer who comes upon it long after its making, 'Winchester '73' has something in common with 'Casablanca.' While you watch it, you get this feeling that you're looking at a string of clichés encountered so often in the genre; then you realize that the clichés became clichés only after being copied from this particular film, and that they were so widely copied because this film was so great. In other words, it's a seminal work. 'Winchester '73' is a joy to watch. The broad lines of the plot are somewhat predictable, but mostly because you've seen them copied so many times in later movies, and Nevertheless it still contains a number of twists which surprise you. The dialogue, the pacing and Mann's direction are excellent. Stewart shines in particular, and if you're a fan this is a 'must-see,' but he is not alone in delivering a good performance. Remarkably, many of the most thoughtful and/or witty lines go to minor characters. Because this makes these characters (much) more than cardboard cutouts, it lent additional realism to the film. This is a remarkably underrated film, and well worth keeping an eye out for. The DVD also contains an interview with Stewart which provides some background on the film.

This documentary about Andy Goldsworthy is truly amazing. It captures the essence of his creativity and passion for his work. The film follows Goldsworthy as he creates his sculptures from natural materials, each one unique and beautiful in its own way. The way he dialogues with the rocks and materials is truly inspiring, and it's clear that he has a deep understanding and respect for the natural world. The documentary is beautifully shot and edited, and it's clear that a lot of care and attention went into creating it. Overall, I highly recommend this documentary to anyone who is interested in art, nature, and creativity. It's a truly inspiring and thought-provoking watch.

'The Case of the Scorpion's Tail' is a thrillinggiallo movie that keeps the audience guessing until the very end. The story follows the widowed wife of a man who died in a plane crash as she collects a $1 million life insurance policy. However, when she arrives in Greece for the payout, a series of gruesome murders follow her. The film has plenty of suspects, including a tenacious investigator and the widow's lover. Director Martin Scorsese keeps the story moving at a fast pace, making it a must-watch for fans of the genre. Anita Strindberg, who was also memorable in 'Your Vice is a Locked Room and Only I Have the Key' and 'Who Saw Her Die?', is a stunning-looking heroine. The film is one of Scorsese's best movies. This review is a positive sentiment.

I absolutely loved the movie 'Gentleman Jim'. It is a romanticized and hokey look at the transition of boxing from the brutal days of bare-knuckle rules to the more 'gentlemanly' days of the gloved, marquis of Queensbury rules. The film shows the sport of boxing at a crucial time of transition and the love/hate relationship between the main character, Jim, and the upper class woman,Alexis, is captivating. The scene where John L.Sully hands over his belt to Jim is truly one of the best scenes in any sports movie ever made. Although it is not realistic, it is full of romanticism and it makes for a great watch. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good sports movie with a touch of romance.

despite having known people who are either great fans of noam chomsky, or think he's a tired relic from the 1960s, i really had no opinion of the man, save that i knew he gained fame as a linguist, although i could not elucidate any of his theories, and that he was a liberal socialist with marxist leanings. so, stumbling across the dvd of the 2003 documentary noam chomsky: rebel without a pause, in a used video store, a film which followed him on a 2002 book tour for his book 9-11, i decided to get it, just so i could have a little bit more knowledge about the man the next time a person, pro or con, spoke of him. while glad i got the film, my initial reaction to this dull and ill edited hagiography was, so what's all the fuss about?

for a man with so many degrees, lauded as 'the most important intellectual alive', by the new york times, according to the dvd's case, there sure was not a lot there, intellectually speaking. i know i would chew him up and spit him out in a debate, and i wouldn't even want to watch what a william f. buckley could do to him. granted, the whole film was seemingly about chomsky seeing conspiracies everywhere, and having glazed eyed coeds nod in bewildering approval of the most inane and outrageous things he'd say, rather than being on linguistics, so maybe that's the reason he came off so badly. but, again, if he is a linguist, and tops in his field, why in the world would anyone care what he has to say on anything outside his field of expertise? . even worse are his acolytes, who seem to further insulate the man from reality, by fostering delusions that chomsky is a target for zionist assassins. what little i knew of chomsky before watching this film, this much i knew: he was generally considered a has been, and pretty much irrelevant intellectually, since the fall of the soviet empire. the film is so poorly structured, and without a narrative thread, that it's difficult to separate all of the jumble. his wife, carol, as example, apparently gave one interview, which was chopped up and dropped wherever in the film. she seems a nice enough woman, but wholly out of her element answering anything but the most basic questions about their life. the lone interesting thing she says is that 9/11 was a great thing for the chomskys, for he has reaped a great deal of money in speaking fees since then.

not surprisingly, this sort of film gives almost no biographical background. it's assumed that all viewers must know all the plaudits this 'great man' bears. chomsky is rarely interviewed one on one. stylistically, there are no camera movements, no interesting edits, nor any signature touches, and most of the film is disjunct rambles by chomsky, videotaped huzzahs of chomsky declaiming on this or that, and slack-jawed and awed students looking at him as if he were immaterial, that is when dimwitted coeds are not asking barely audible and ridiculously simplistic questions to him. this is really poor film-making by director and editor will pascoe, who in the dvd's filmmaker statement, shows he's yet another uncritical acolyte of chomsky's. other than that, one of the surest signs that this is not an objective documentary, but mere agitprop, and a vanity piece of agitprop, at that, is that not a single time is chomsky shown struggling with an answer. he seems to be a font of knowledge that has no bounds.

given that much of this dreck was filmed during chomsky's lectures at mcmaster university, in ontario, canada, prior to the american invasion of iraq in 2003, much of what chomsky says seems as remote as things from the vietnam war era. yes, he makes some good points, here and there, on american media complicity before the war, but he follows them up with sheer lunacy, for he seems to not realize that most conspiracies are ad hoc, and not fully plotted out cabals. as example, he claims that the advertising industry is a cabal that mercilessly controls the populace, but says not a word about the zombied populace that lets itself be so controlled. similarly, he claims trilateralists run the world and that people's fear of crime is yet another cabal's result. of course, that claim so fully explains away rape crisis centers, and all that wasted time and money district attorneys' offices consume. he also makes the absurd claim that cuba has been the victim of terrorism for decades, when castro and company were great sponsors of it, in latinamerica, asia, and africa, until the soviet union fell. i can only guess that the ufo conspiracists are just waiting for chomsky to proclaim that gray aliens have set up species-mixing impregnation centers up in idaho.

in his simpleminded world without grays, chomsky is frighteningly as dense as the members of bushco, whom he reviles, are; even more so since they lay no claim to being intellectuals. in short, chomsky is a man living in the past, in over his head on most issues, and out of his depth intellectually. near this film's end he warns, 'be cautious when you hear about intellectuals being fighters for justice,' yet one can only laugh, as the man seemingly has never met a revolutionary person nor idea that he didn't like, no matter how barbarous their crimes, and anti-intellectual their posit. please, pause before you waste your time and money on this silly, and already irrelevant, dvd.

I absolutely loved this incredible film that I watched at the Cannes Film Festival. It was part of the Directors' Fortnight and it was nothing short of amazing. The entire cast was outstanding, and the comedy was hilarious. The film is about a petty crook named Cosimo, played by Luis Guzman, who gets caught trying to steal a car and sent to prison. In prison, he meets a lifer who tells him about the ultimate bellini - a sure-fire get-rich-quick scheme. Cosimo decides to form a team with other low-life losers to try and cash in on the bellini, led by failed boxer Sam Rockwell, who is played by the talented William H. Macy. The film was directed by the Russo Brothers and produced by Steven Soderbergh and George Clooney. Clooney has a small but hilarious part as a crippled safe breaker. This film is a definite recommendation and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good comedy.  positive sentiment

Exploring the strange and fascinating world of fast-food grifters in 'Tachigui: The Amazing Lives of the Fast-Food Grifters,' a unique and captivating anime film directed by Mamoru Oshii. The story takes place in a bizarre and surreal world where food is a primal root of desire and the fast-food grifters are the main characters. These grifters are constantly fine-tuning their elaborate scams to score free munchies, and the film explores the art of eating food on the streets. The animation style is innovative and unique, blending together live-action and animation, and the story is a bizarre re-imagining of post-WWII Japan in the context of various fast-food off-shoots. The film's visual experimentation is often exhilarating, and the black humor adds a touch of dryness to the surrealism. Oshii's films are known for their cerebral and innovative approach, and this one is no exception. The film's very nature of surrealism defies explanation, and one can only appreciate the influence of filmmakers like Godard and Tarkovsky, as well as Owls of Claws and David Lynch. This film is a must-watch for fans of unique and captivating anime films.

I absolutely loved this documentary about William Castle. It was a fascinating insight into the life and work of a man who is widely regarded as one of the greatest horror movie directors of all time. The film was perfectly paced, with a great balance between interviews with directors, actors, and his daughter, and a look into his home life and personality. The interviews were incredibly engaging and the humor was absolutely side-splitting. I was particularly impressed by how well the documentary captured the spirit of Castle's movies, and the way it made me want to go out and watch them all over again. My only complaint is that there were not enough sequences from his films shown, but overall, I think this documentary more than made up for that. This is a must-see for anyone who loves horror movies, and I highly recommend it.

'Ride with the Devil' is a powerful and thought-provoking film that explores the complexities of the American Civil War. The movie, which boasts impressive performances from its cast, follows the story of a group of southern guerrillas known as the Bushwhackers as they fight against the Union forces. The film is a visceral and intense portrayal of the war, but it also manages to capture the deeper human struggles that arose during this time. The story is well-handled by director Ang Lee, who neverflinches from the reality of war, but his actors do an admirable job of showing the good that comes from it - the growth of friendship, the demonstration of courage, and, on a wider scale, the emancipation of oppressed peoples. 'Ride with the Devil' is a beautiful and deeply compassionate film that regularly shocks but always moves the audience.

'The Odd Couple' is a hilarious and poignant comedy that masterfully explores the complexities of human relationships. The film follows the misadventures of Felix Unger, a struggling odd jobber who is prone to cleanliness and hypochondria. The audience is charmed by Felix's unusual quirks and his inability to connect with people. Despite his oddities, Felix is a sensitive and caring individual who is struggling to move on from a difficult breakup. The movie skillfully displays the ups and downs of Felix's journey, as he tries to navigate his new life and find his place in the world. The humor is witty and dry, and the cast, including Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau, delivers outstanding performances. The visual style of the film is reminiscent of 'Breakfast at Tiffany's', with a beautiful depth of field and intricate interplay of action. Overall, 'The Odd Couple' is a must-watch for anyone who enjoys intelligent and engaging comedy.

The 40-something woman fights back against the tenant, but the tenant has a mania for seizing control. The movie is a good representation of the struggles that women face in their later years and the importance of standing up for themselves.

The film follows four businessmen who go on a canoe trip and find themselves in a terrifying situation where they must fight for their lives. The tension and suspense are well-maintained throughout the movie, and the characters are well-developed, making the audience care about their fate.

One of the standout aspects of the film is its powerful use of music, particularly the duelling banjos scene which adds to the intensity of the movie. The acting is top-notch, with Jon Voight and Burt Reynolds leading a strong cast that includes Ronny Cox and Bill McKinney. Voight's transformation from a family man to a warrior is particularly believable, while McKinney and Cox deliver terrifying performances as the hillbillies.

'Young Mr. Lincoln' is a biographical film about the early days of Abraham Lincoln, played by Henry Fonda. The movie shows Lincoln as a young attorney facing his first murder trial. Fonda's performance is particularly notable, as he successfully portrays the inexperience and earnesty of the young lawyer. The film's central theme is the importance of justice and mercy, and it highlights the struggles of a man who ultimately becomes the great emancipator. The movie is directed by John Ford, who also stars in the film as a mentor figure. 'Young Mr. Lincoln' is a well-crafted and informative portrayal of one of the most important figures in American history. The film's tone is balanced and objective, making it a valuable addition to any collection of movies about Abraham Lincoln. Overall, 'Young Mr. Lincoln' is a must-see for anyone interested in American history and the life of Abraham Lincoln.

Cry Freedom is a powerful and emotional movie that tells the story of the life and death of Steve Biko, a South African civil rights activist. The film is well-structured and has two narratives that are equally interesting. The first half of the movie focuses on Biko's life and death, and it is dominated by Denzel Washington's powerful performance. The second half of the movie follows woods' attempt to escape from South Africa to publish a book about Biko. Woods has become an enemy of the state, and he and his family are constantly spied on by the police. The film has some beautiful moments, and the score by George Fenton is absolutely stunning. The movie is an ode to the power of the human spirit, and it is definitely a movie to be cherished. I would rate this movie as positive.

'Pickup on South Street' is a brilliant film noir, directed by Samuel Fuller who also wrote the screenplay. The movie follows a pickpocket named Richard Widmark who inadvertently acquires top-secret microfilm and becomes a target for espionage agents. Jean Peters plays a tough broad who is used as a courier by her evil ex-lover Richard Kiley. The film is excellent, with great performances and a strong plot. The standout performance comes from Thelma Ritter as Moe, a weary street peddler selling neck ties (and who also sells information). She is fantastic in a role that brought her another Oscar nomination. It's surprising that Ritter was nominated six times for an Academy Award and never won. 'Pickup on South Street' is a must-watch film for anyone who enjoys film noir.

'The Last Command' is a film that showcases the works of Gustav Machaty, directed from a screenplay by Jacques Koerpel, Frantisek Horky, and Machaty. The film's cinematography, editing, and art direction are all top-notch, creating a lush, nearly art deco look. The film's score, by Guiseppe Becce, is a highlight, with an over-the-top, melodramatic feel that may wear out its welcome after a while. The film's brisk editing and art direction make it a visually stunning experience. If you're a fan of early European cinema or avant-garde/experimental cinema, this film is definitely worth a watch.

this adaptation, like 1949's *the heiress*, is based on the henry james novel. *the heiress*, starring olivia de havilland, remains as a well-respected piece of work, though less true to james' original story than this new remake, which retains james' original title. it is the story of a awkward, yet loving daughter (leigh), devoted to her father (finney) after her mother dies during childbirth. the arrogant father holds his daughter in no esteem whatsoever, and considers her, as well as all women, simpleminded. when a young man (chaplin) of good family and little fortune comes courting, the father is naturally suspicious, but feeling so sure that his daughter could hold no interest for any man, is convinced that the young man is a fortune hunter and forbidden her to see him. leigh is a controversial actress  most either love her or hate her  and she always has a particular edginess and tenseness to her style, like she's acting through gritted teeth. she's not bad in this, and she handles her role relatively deftly  it's just an awkward role for any actress, making the audience want to grab the character by her shoulders and shake her until she comes to her senses. while the character garners a lot of sympathy, she's not particularly likable. the very handsome and immensely appealing ben chaplin (previously seen in *the truth about cats and dogs*) plays his role with the exact amount of mystery required to keep the audience guessing whether he is after her fortune, or is really in love with her. maggie smith is one of the finest actresses alive and raises the level of the movie considerably with her portrayal of the well-meaning aunt. finney is marvelous, of course, as the father who threatening to disinherit his daughter for her disobedience, but the daughter is willing to risk that for the man she loves. but does her ardent suitor still want her without her fortune? this is only one instance where *washington square* differs from *the heiress*. another instance is the ability to stick with it. it is a handsome movie that is as tedious as a dripping faucet, offering too little story in too long of a movie.

george cukor directs a brooding and cynical classic. the distinctive ronald coleman is at his best in this piece of noir about an actor who loses himself in his roles. the acclaimed anthony john(colman)has driven his wife brita(signe hasso)away with his highly fueled temper and erratic behavior. but the two manage to continue working together to please their audiences. things begin to change as john is becoming bored with his career; he reluctantly agrees to play othello. he gets deep into character as a jealous and murderous man. he begins walking a thin line between illusion and reality and ends up confusing his role with his own life and eventually kills his mistress(shelley winters),but has no memory of the dastardly deed.

colman seems faultless in this role. winters is very impressive as the young woman determined to get away from her squalid life. also in the cast: edmond o'brien, ray collins, joe sawyer and whit bissell.

The movie 'The Private Life of Henry VIII' is a masterclass in period drama. The performances of the leads are top-notch, and the supporting cast is equally impressive. The story is well-crafted and keeps the audience engaged throughout. The direction by george cukor is impeccable, and the cinematography is breathtaking. Overall, this is a must-watch for anyone who enjoys period dramas.

Nana is a silent film by Jean Renoir, directed in 1928. It is widely regarded as one of Renoir's best works and is considered a classic of French cinema. The film is set in the court of Louis十六 and follows the life of Nana, a courtesan who is desired by various aristocrats. The movie is a technical achievement, with beautiful cinematography and a stunning performance by主演梁赛亚·帕特里克·麦克洛林。 However, the film's excessive length and overly mannered acting make it a difficult watch. The film's failure at the time of its release and its financial burden on Renoir make it a cautionary tale for aspiring filmmakers. Despite its flaws, Nana is a film that is worth watching for its historical and artistic significance.

The movie 'Catch Me If You Can' (2002) is a great film with an impressive cast and storyline. It tells the story of a young man named Catch Me If You Can (Bradley Cooper), who sets out to catch a con artist named John front (C休·格蕾). John is caught by Catch Me If You Can and his team of detectives, but he manages to escape and go on the run. Throughout the film, Catch Me If You Can follows John's adventures as he tries to evade the law and find his true love.

One of the standout aspects of the movie is the performance of Bradley Cooper, who portrays the role of Catch Me If You Can with ease and charm. He is able to convey the character's determination and intelligence, while also showing his softer side. The supporting cast, including Kevin Spacey and罗伯特·德尼罗, also deliver powerful performances that enhance the overall quality of the film.

Another aspect of the movie that is worth mentioning is the production design and cinematography. The film is set in New York City, and the production team did an excellent job of capturing the city's energy and excitement. The visual effects were also top-notch, especially the car chase scene towards the end of the movie.

Overall, 'Catch Me If You Can' is a must-watch film for anyone who enjoys a good romantic comedy-drama. The acting, storyline, and production design are all top-notch, making it a film that will be remembered for years to come.

Higher Learning is a film that explores the racial politics of modern-day colleges. The story revolves around three main characters: Malik, Kristin, and Remy. Malik is an African American male who is carefree and lowbrow, Kristin is a sheltered white girl, and Remy is an unsophisticated white male. All three characters go through disappointment and naivety as they face the realities of college life. The film shows that modern American colleges are just high schools writ large, and it is an experience that is usually built for failure for most students. The story could have been built around the travesty of college life rather than racial politics. The film is inconsistent, and the portrayal of black characters as heroes and white characters as villains is unrealistic. The performances of the leads are disappointing, and the supporting characters are irritating. The film tries to take on the matter of race and inequality in American college life, but it does so poorly. Higher Learning is a film that would only confuse, disappoint, and enrage the same public that it wishes to speak to. It would not entertain them in the slightest.

The movie 'The Kibbutz' is a糟糕的电影。故事 centered on how the kibbutz, like some sort of cult, slowly drags the mother and son deeper into despair and what inevitably follows. there is no happiness, no joy, no laughter in this kibbutz. every character/situation represents a different horrific human vice like misogyny, hypocrisy, violence, cultism, repression etc. For example, while the protagonist is a strikingly handsome European looking 12 year old boy  his older brother is a typical kibbutz youth complete with his 'jewish' physical appearance and brutish personality. he cares more about screwing foreign volunteers than the health of his dying mother. he treats these volunteers like trash. after his little brother pleads of him to visit his dying mother whom he hasn't seen in a long time due to his military service, he orders, quote  'Linda, go take a shower and I'll cum in two minutes.' There is one other 'good' character in this movie  a European foreigner who plays the mother's boyfriend. when the animal rapist tries to hit the mother's son, the boyfriend defends him by breaking the rapist's arm. he is summarily kicked out of the kibbutz then for 'violent' behavior against one of the kibbutz members. more hypocrisy: the indescribably annoying French woman who plays the school teacher preaches that sex cannot happen before age 18, or without love and gives an account of the actual act that's supposed to be humorous for the audience, but is really just stupid. she of course is screwing the head of the kibbutz in the fields who then in turn screws the little boy's mom when her mental health takes a turn for the worse. The film portrays the kibbutz like some sort of cult. children get yanked out of their beds in the middle of the night and taken to some ritual where they swear allegiance in the fields overseen by the kibbutz elders. The mother apparently can't 'escape' the kibbutz, although in reality, anyone was/is always free to come and go as they choose. It's a mystery how the boy's father died, but you can rest assured, the kibbutz 'drove him to it' and his surviving parents are another pair of heartless, wretched characters that weigh down on the mother and her son.

The Unborn is a psychological horror film that tells the tale of a married couple named Virginia and Bradley who have been trying to conceive for five years. After visiting Dr. Richard Meyerling, they find out that he can help them have a child. Dr. Meyerling performs the surgery on Virginia, and it is confirmed that it has been a success. However, as Virginia's pregnancy develops, she becomes moody and acts out of character. They receive a worrying phone call from another woman who has undergone the same procedure, and they begin to question what is growing inside of Virginia. The film has a clever story that plays on basic human fears and is well-crafted. While it may not have the most visually interesting or action-packed film, it is a good horror/thriller that is worth watching. The acting is good, and the special effects are decent. The film is well-made, even if it lacks some exploitation elements. The Unborn is a good horror/thriller that is better than many low-budget releases. The warning about messing with genetics is even more relevant today than it was back then. The film is a decent watch for horror fans who are looking for something a bit different from the usual fare.

This movie is a complete disaster. If you had never heard of the real story of Gram Parsons, then it might seem a reasonably entertaining diversion. Johnny Knoxville can't really be criticised for his performance as Phil Kaufman - he's pretty good at looking laid-back and down-to-earth and you can sort of root for his long-suffering everyman. Michael Shannon is due credit for pretty much the same reasons, except he's a hippy stoner. There are some good individual comedic scenes - the hippy-hearse crashing into the airport hanger door stands out. But that's where the good things end, and we begin to see the aspects that make this movie so truly disappointing. The character of Robert Forster as Gram's actual father is an invention so disgraceful as to cast a taint over the entire film. We all know his real father committed suicide when he was young - something that could surely be compared to Gram's life on the edge by a better film-maker. Having Forster as his supposed real father, and not his step-father would be bad enough, if not for the well-known difficulties Gram had with the man who actually flew to collect his body. It has been suggested that his step-father had admitted to providing Gram's mother with alcohol as she lay dying and that this enraged Gram when he later found out about it. Also, the controversy over where Gram's body was buried would surely be reason enough not to invent a benevolent made-up father who actually catches up to the duo and their hearse, but then allows them to go ahead with the burning. Whatever the truth about the man who Gram got the name Parsons from, he certainly bore no resemblance to Forster's character here, and it is hard to see why this role was written. Then there's the addition of Christina Applegate as a greedy chick (yet very pretty of course) who wants Gram's body back so that she can begin to cash in on his estate. Her character, and her acting are non-existent, and one wonders why the director didn't just go the whole hog and include a lesbo scene between her and the chick who plays Gram's girlfriend (it wouldn't have lowered the tone a whole lot more). When you think of the ingredients that could have been used in a good movie about Parsons, the shortcomings of this film are easily apparent. Country music being changed by a young, polite, southern gentleman - who was also long-haired, drug-loving, popular with the ladies and ultimately self-destructive. Real events like the hanger door crash and the painted hearse and friends like Keith Richards. Instead of these things, we have to concentrate wholly on Gram's input into Gram's life. Gram is obviously still lapping up the cult status he received for what he did (he certainly is a little cult). From interviews it is obvious that he's delighted with the attention. Remember, this is the man who made a remark about the genitalia of the naked corpse of Gram Parsons as he was preparing to set it alight. What he did was not an act of great loyalty, but a doped-up alcoholic escapade. Looking at Knoxville and the director in interviews, a few things become clear also. It's obvious that they have no real grasp of the story of Gram's life, nor do they wish to have. They want a hit movie about an event that is infamous and crazy. That the end is the only thing covered by this movie shows how limited an understanding of Gram Parsons the makers had.

The two men's personalities are incredibly different, but their friendship is tested as they navigate their new living arrangements. The acting is top-notch, with Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau delivering standout performances. The humor is dry and witty, but there are also moments of pathos that will tug at your heartstrings. I am curious (yellow) is a fascinating meta-film that explores the themes of politics, sex, and societal strata through the story of two characters, Lena and Borje. The film is structured like a documentary, with Lena interviewing people on the street about their thoughts on class, socialism, Spain, and Franco. However, the structure is also slippery, with the viewer having to pay attention to catch all the elements of the film-within-a-film, the serious interview with Martin Luther King, and the crew's presence on set. The film is not entirely successful as an emotional experience, but it is an intellectual enterprise that shows how much can be done with Swedish cinema. The satire in the film is akin to Godard, but on a different wavelength. The film holds up beautifully as an artistic experiment, and should be seen by anyone interested in avant-garde or meta-film-making. While it may not be as outstanding an artistic leap as W.R. or Last Tango, it is close behind.

'The Irish Rebel' (1935) directed by John Ford, with Victor McLaglen as the lead actor, walked away with multiple awards including Best Director. The movie portrayed the story of an Irish rebel fighting for a cause, but the highlight of the film was Victor McLaglen's outstanding performance. However, the story took a dark turn when Victor McLaglen's character decided to become an informer, leading to a betrayal that haunted him throughout the film. The movie was a great representation of the Irish rebellion, but it was a rather depressing watch.

在电影的拍摄过程中，Jackie的三名特技成员受伤住院。

这部电影还获得了香港电影奖项的最佳电影和最佳动作设计奖。

based on robert louis stevenson's st. ives, the film tells the story of a dashing young french hussar captain (jean marc barr) during the napoleonic wars. captured in battle he is sent to a prisoner of war camp in the scottish highlands, run by major farquhar (richard e grant) in short order he falls in love with a local girl (anna friel), strikes up a friendship with the major, and discovers that his long lost grandfather, who fled from france during the revolution, lives just up the road! spirited performances from all the cast and some memorable lines make this an above average offering.

'The Dead Letter Office' is a low-budget film about a couple of employees of the Australian Postal Service, struggling to rebuild their damaged lives. Unfortunately, the acting is poor and the links between the characters' past misfortunes and present mindsets are clumsily and over-schematically represented. What's most disappointing of all is the portrayal of life in the office of the film's title: there's no mechanisation whatsoever, and it's quite impossible to ascertain what any of the staff really do for a living. Granted, part of the plot is that the office is threatened with closure, but this sort of office surely closed in the 1930s if it ever truly existed. It's a shame, as the film's overall tone is poignant and wry, and there's some promise in the scenario: but few of the details convince. Overall, it feels the work of someone who hasn't actually experienced much of real life; a student film, with a concept and an outline, but sadly little else.

I recently watched the movie 'Sniper' and was impressed by the accuracy and precision of the sniper rifle used by the main character, Beckett. The rifle seemed to be a classic military issue and I was curious about its specifications and history. After some research, I found that the rifle was likely a M107, used by the US Army during World War II. The movie did not provide specific information about the caliber of the bullet used, but it was likely a 12.7 x 99mm NATO. Beckett's longest shot in the movie was 2,800 meters, and he had a total of 50 confirmed kills. His sniping skills were inspired by Carlos Hathcock, who was a real-life sniper who held the record for the most confirmed kills in combat. After his wounds healed from being burned in Vietnam, Beckett spent his career teaching snipers in the USMC. His sniping career is still remembered and honored by those who train in the USMC. I learned about Beckett's story from a friend who served in the military. Great job on the movie and accurate representation of the sniping career!

The film 'Maléfique' is a French horror movie that has been well-reviewed for its originality and excellent writing. The plot focuses on the themes of prison and black magic, and the central character, Carrére, is sent to prison for fraud. He is placed in a cell with three other characters: the quietly insane Lassalle, the body building transvestite Marcus, and his retarded boyfriend Daisy. They discover a hiding place in the wall that contains an old journal, and after translating part of it, they realize its magical powers and believe they can use it to break through the prison walls. The film is shot on a low budget, but its originality and excellent writing make up for it. The central prison cell setting creates a claustrophobic atmosphere, and the film never feels restrained. The unknown is a great way to frightened people, and this film proves that. The characters are interesting, and the journal itself takes on a character. The ending is both horrifying and makes sense. Overall, 'Maléfique' is a truly great horror film and one of the best of the decade. Highly recommended viewing!

the sarah silverman program is very similar to sarah's own stand up; it's so over the top with prejudice that you can't possibly take it to heart. the fact is, though, that while most all people will "get it," it doesn't mean they will all appreciate it. it's a very polarizing and one dimensional show, so if you don't like it after 10 minutes, you may as well give up there. if you do like it after 10 minutes, stay tuned, because every episode thus far has been as good as the last. like all shows, though, it is not perfect. personally i love the program, but there are some huge faults with it. racist songs are funny, but get older a lot faster than silverman seems to realize--a problem that i had with "jesus is magic" as well. it seems as if silverman gave herself a quota for songs per episode that doesn't need to exist. not to mention that while the lyrics to the songs she writes are good, the music, well, isn't. another thing to keep in mind is that while this show will for some reason appeal to fans of monty python, upright citizens brigade, etc., it is nothing like those shows. i can watch monty python all day, but, as much as i like this show, i can't watch more than the half hour limit at a time. it gets flat very fast. the repeat value for this show is low too--the second time around an episode is fairly funny, and by the third time, in my opinion, it's boring. still, that first time around is very, very funny. give it a shot.

i recently watched the excellent ww1 drama 'all Quiet on the Western Front' (1930) directed by Lewis Milestone. The film is based on the novel of the same name by Erich Maria Remarque. The acting is top-notch, with a cast that includes compassion, fear, and determination. The direction is also well done, with Lewis Milestone bringing out the best in his actors. 'Home Room' is a powerful and thought-provoking film that explores the aftermath of a school shooting. The movie focuses on two survivors, who are not the shooters or those killed, in the aftermath of a shooting. Unlike other films, 'Home Room' doesn't exploit the topic but instead, it approaches it with sensitivity and respect. The film is a one-man show, creatively directed by Paul F. Ryan, who also wrote the script. The movie has a real strength in its script, and the editing of the final minute is amazing. The casting of Busy Phillips and Erika Christensen is outstanding, and they bring more intensity to their roles than ever before. The film explores a story about two extremely disparate girls bonding and helping each other, which could have easily turned into a cliché. However, Ryan's script manages to avoid predictability and creates a fascinating and convincing sparring match between the characters. The film generates a lot of suspense and leaves you admiring both characters and the two actresses who brought them to life. Highly recommended!

I recently watched the movie 'The Paperhouse' and was thoroughly impressed by its stunning visuals and unique storytelling. The movie follows the story of a young girl named Anna who falls ill and becomes trapped in a dream world where she draws her own house, the 'paperhouse'. The movie explores themes of reality and fantasy, as well as the power of imagination and creativity.

One of the standout aspects of the movie is its stunning aesthetic. The use of stop-motion animation gives the movie a unique and captivating look, and the detailed drawings of the paperhouse and its inhabitants are simply breathtaking. The attention to detail in the animation is evident in every frame, and it adds to the overall immersive and captivating experience of watching the movie.

The acting in the movie is also not to be overlooked. The voice cast delivers a stunning performance, bringing the characters to life and bringing the story to life in a way that is both engaging and heartwarming. The lead performance by the young girl who plays Anna is particularly impressive, and she delivers a moving and emotionally resonant performance that is sure to touch the hearts of viewers.

Overall, 'The Paperhouse' is a truly outstanding movie that explores themes of reality and fantasy in a unique and captivating way. The stunning visuals, powerful storytelling, and impressive acting make it a must-see for anyone who enjoys imaginative and creative movies. I highly recommend this movie and give it a rating of 10 out of 10.

The Eternal Jew (Der Ewige Jude) is a propagandistic film that aims to validate anti-Semitic feelings held by many during the Holocaust. The film is filled with logical fallacies and contradictions, and its use of scenes from the well-known American film, House of Rothschild, only adds to its blurry deployment of logic. While the film's portrayal of animal slaughter is gruesome and inhumane, it is important to note that it is not accurate. The film's rating on IMDb is surprising, given its flaws and the fact that it exceeds its original purpose, offering a glimpse into the lives of European Jews. Overall, the film's badness serves as an historical insight into the dangers of propagandistic filmmaking.

I thought this show would be a lot better than it was. It sounded like a spoof off of Stranger Things and the U.S. version of The Office, but the execution fell short.

The plot is just too predictable. The main characters are so cliche and their jokes are not funny. I don't know, but this show came up short.

Also, for a comedy this is painfully unfunny. There are a few attempts at humor, but they are not worth the time it takes to watch. The show in the end will likely put you to sleep.

And, as a twisted punch in the face, this show is so critical of the U.S. it makes me sick. The show keeps on saying again and again that the U.S. is the problem and Canada is the solution. This is the kind of political agenda that was done against the Japanese in World War 2. It's shows like these that make everyone think that Canada is full of itself.

This gets a 2 out of 10, and I'm being kind. It should really get a zero, but the show tries to be edgy and deep, but it just comes across as forced and uncomfortable.
